name: Bolivia
takeaway: Bolivia is highly exposed to PRC influence. On the one hand, in the domains of Media, Academia and Society, it is clear that little effort is needed by the PRC to gain leverage, while on the economic side, Bolivia sees in the PRC a great ally, especially when it comes to debts swaps and trade. This has foreign policy repercussions, with former president of Bolivia, Evo Morales, being a vocal support of the PRC.

The Law Enforcement and Military Domains are the less exposed to the PRC. This could be because of the close historical relationship of the Bolivian military and law enforcement with the US, and in particular Drug Enforcement Administration.

Over the last few years, Bolivia has experienced an internal political crisis that made it more difficult for the PRC and the Bolivian government to keep a fluid relationship. However, trips and exchanges have continued, as captured by Indicators in the Media, Academia and Domestic Politics Domains.
description-1: In 2023, Bolivia had a GDP per capita of US$3,701 and a total population of 12.16 million people.
description-2: Bolivia established diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China in 1985. Bolivia was ranked 124th in Reporters Without Borders’ 2024 World Press Freedom Index, and rated Partly Free in Freedom House‘s 2024 Global Freedom Index, with a score of 66/100.

Foreign Policy.evidence: Bolivia received a lot of donations of vaccines during COVID and still receives support and donations from China of that kind. But most importantly, financial aid from China came to Bolivia through the use of RMBs in Bolivian economy when they had ran out of US dollars in their Central Bank.

Domestic Politics.evidence:
The following Bolivian cities have sister-city ties with PRC cities: La Paz and Dalian; Cochabanba and Kunming; Potosí and Lhasa.

Though they are important cities in Bolivia, these sister cities agreements are quite old and don't seem to have generated much over the last few years.

Technology.evidence: Three companies, one public and two private, provide telecomunications services in Bolivia and none is linked to PRC-connected entities. But it is worth mentioning that China Piesat was contracted to provide satellite monitoring services to Bolivia.

Technology.evidence: Apparently, ENTEL is the only Bolivian company using Huawei and ZTE technology networks but it is the most important telecommunications company in Bolivia with more than half of the market share, thus it is significant. However, there have been some irregularities denounced on those agreements.
